title: Youth Thematic Brief Population Analysis

1 Youth brief
This book presents population analysis and NPower impact assessments to support the youth thematic brief.

title: 2  Youth in the Canadian Labour Market

title: 2  Youth in the Canadian Labour Market
text:
2.1.1 Youth
In this report, we use the term “youth” to refer to individuals of working age (15 to 29). This is consistent with definitions used by Statistics Canada and the International Labour Organization.


2.1.2 Newcomer
This report defines newcomers as immigrants to Canada who landed 10 or fewer years prior to the reference year. Conventional definitions of newcomers use a 5-year window, but the LFS PUMF does not distinguish between immigrants who landed 5 or fewer years ago and those who landed 6 to 10 years ago.


2.1.3 School Months
Current enrollment in either high school or post-secondary education is one dimension of the segmentation model developed below. While the LFS PUMF variable SCHOOLN indicates current attendance, it does indicate current enrollment. This means that, for example, a student who is on summer break would be classified as not currently attending school, even though they are still enrolled. To address this issue, we limit impacted components of the analysis to typically active university terms (September to May).

section: 2.3 How have youth fared in the Canadian labour market?
text:
2.3 How have youth fared in the Canadian labour market?
Unsurprisingly, youth in Canada have lower participation, employment, and earnings than non-youth. Of note is the disproportionate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on youth employment and participation rates in 2020, and their slower recovery compared to non-youth. Whether this portends a long-term shift in the labour market remains to be seen, but it is clear that youth entering or returning to the labour market in the near future will encounter a different landscape than their pre-pandemic counterparts.

2.3.1 Labour market rate indicators
Table 2.1 presents annualized average rates of participation, employment, unemployment, enrollment, and NEET status among youth in Canada from 2015 to 2024.
It suggests the following:

Youth participation and employment rates are consistently lower than those of the non-youth population.
NEET rates among youth are consistently lower due to much higher rates of enrollment in education.
Youth participation, employment, and NEET rates jumped in 2020, but have largely recovered to pre-pandemic levels.



Show code
gt_spanners <- function(g, ...) {
  g_ <- g

  spanners <- rlang::list2(...)

  purrr::iwalk(
    spanners, 
    function(pattern, label) {
      g_ <<- g_ |> 
        gt::tab_spanner(
          label = label, 
          columns = matches(pattern)
        )
    }
  )
  g_
}

lfs_source_note <- function(g, u = "Working-age population (15-64)") {
  g |> 
    gt::tab_source_note(
      source_note = "Source: Labour Force Survey Public Use Microdata File (LFS PUMF), Statistics Canada"
    ) |> 
    gt::tab_source_note(
      source_note = glue::glue("Universe: {u}")
    )
}


t01 <- d |> 
  filter(school_month) |> 
  group_by(SURVYEAR, youth_fct) |> 
  summarize(
    participation = weighted.mean(participating_lgl, FINALWT),
    employment = weighted.mean(employed_lgl, FINALWT),
    unemployment = weighted.mean(unemployed_lgl, FINALWT, na.rm = TRUE),
    enrollment = weighted.mean(enrolled_lgl, FINALWT),
    neet = weighted.mean(neet_lgl, FINALWT)
  ) |> 
  ungroup()
## `summarise()` has grouped output by 'SURVYEAR'. You can override using the
## `.groups` argument.

t01 |> 
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = youth_fct, 
    values_from = c(participation, employment, unemployment, enrollment, neet)
  ) |> 
  gt::gt() |> 
  gt::fmt_percent(
    columns = c(-SURVYEAR),
    decimals = 0
  ) |> 
  gt_spanners(
    "Participation" = "participation", 
    "Employment" = "^employment", 
    "Unemployment" = "unemployment",
    "Enrollment" = "enrollment",
    "NEET" = "neet"
  ) |> 
  gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |> 
  gt::cols_label_with(
    columns = c(-SURVYEAR), 
    fn = function(x) {
      x |> 
        stringr::str_replace("^.*(A|Y).*(\\d{2}-\\d{2})$", "\\1(\\2)")
    }
  ) |> 
  lfs_source_note()

Universe: Working-age population (15-64)











Figure 2.1 isolates the gap between youth and non-youth in participation, employment, and NEET rates. It highlights the disproportionate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on youth employment and participation rates in 2020, and the slower recovery of youth employment and participation rates compared to those of non-youth.


Show code
m01 <- d |> 
  filter(school_month) |>
  pivot_longer(
    c(participating_lgl, employed_lgl, neet_lgl),
    names_to = "var", 
    values_to = "y"
  ) |> 
  group_by(SURVYEAR, var) |> 
  group_nest(.key = "dat") |> 
  mutate(
    mod = map(
      dat,
      ~ lm(
        y ~ youth_lgl + factor(SURVMNTH), 
        data = .x,
        weights = FINALWT
      )
    ), 
    tab = map(
      mod, 
      ~ broom::tidy(.x, conf.int = TRUE) |> 
        dplyr::bind_rows(
          multcomp::glht(.x, "(Intercept) + youth_lgl = 0") |>
            broom::tidy() |>
            dplyr::select(
                -null.value
            ) |>
            dplyr::rename(
                term = contrast,
                p.value = adj.p.value
            ) |>
            dplyr::mutate(
                conf.low = estimate - 1.96 * std.error,
                conf.high = estimate + 1.96 * std.error
            )
        )
    )
  )

m01 |> 
  select(SURVYEAR, var, tab) |> 
  unnest(tab) |> 
  filter(term == "youth_lgl") |>
  ggplot(aes(SURVYEAR)) + 
  facet_wrap(~var) + 
  ggdist::stat_halfeye(
    aes(ydist = distributional::dist_normal(estimate, std.error))
  ) + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = 2015:2024, 
    labels = function(x) glue::glue("'{x - 2000}")
  ) + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = c(-.05, -.1, -.15, -.2),
    limits = c(-.2, -.05),
    labels = scales::percent_format(suffix = " ppt", accuracy = 1)
  ) + 
  labs(
    title = "Rate gaps between youth and non-youth",
    y = "Gap"
  )








Figure 2.1







2.3.2 Job quality indicators
Table 2.2 shows a selection of job quality indicators among employed youth in Canada from 2015 to 2024.
In it, we observe the following: - Hourly earnings among employed youth are consistently lower than those of their non-youth counterparts. - Employed youth are much more likely to occupy part-time or temporary positions than non-youth employees. - Involuntary part-time work is more common among employed youth than among non-youth employees.

    as.integer(COWMAIN) < 3
  ) |> 
  group_by(SURVYEAR, youth_fct) |> 
  summarize(
    hrlyearn = weighted.mean(HRLYEARN, FINALWT),
    part_time = weighted.mean(FTPTMAIN == "Part-time", FINALWT),
    involuntary_pt = weighted.mean(job_involuntary_pt_lgl, FINALWT),
    temporary = weighted.mean(job_temporary_lgl, FINALWT), 
    .groups = "drop"
  )

    decimals = 0
  ) |>

  ) |>

    columns = c(-SURVYEAR),

      x |> 
        stringr::str_replace("^.*(A|Y).*(\\d{2}-\\d{2})$", "\\1(\\2)")
    }
  ) |> 
  lfs_source_note(u = "Employed, employees")

Figure 2.2 shows the gap in hourly earnings between youth and non-youth employees in Canada from 2015 to 2024. It suggests that earnings among employed youth have followed a similar trajectory to employment rates, in that they dropped disproportionately in 2020 and have lagged behind the recovery of non-youth earnings.

  group_nest(.key = "dat") |> 
  mutate(

      dat,

        z_hrlyearn ~ youth_lgl + factor(SURVMNTH), 
        data = .x,
        weights = FINALWT
      )
    ), 
    tab = map(
      mod, 
      ~broom::tidy(.x, conf.int = TRUE) |>

title: 2  Youth in the Canadian Labour Market
section: 2.4 How has the youth population changed?
text:
2.4 How has the youth population changed?
The youth population in Canada has grown more educated and more diverse over the past decade. The rate of PSE attainment increased by 9.6%, while the rate of newcomer representation among youth increased by 35.2% over the same period.

2.4.1 National representation of PSE and newcomer status
Table 2.3 shows the proportion of youth in Canada who have attained post-secondary education and the proportion of youth who are newcomers from 2015 to 2024. Both indicators have increased over the past decade. The rate of post-secondary attainment among youth increased by 3.8 ppt between 2015 and 2024, while the rate of newcomer representation among youth has increased by 3.0 ppt over the same period.


Show code
t03 <- d |> 
  filter(youth_lgl == 1, school_month) |> 
  group_by(SURVYEAR) |> 
  summarize(
    pse = weighted.mean(has_pse_lgl, FINALWT),
    newcomer = weighted.mean(newcomer_lgl, FINALWT)
  )

t03 |> 
  gt::gt() |> 
  gt::fmt_percent(
    columns = c(-SURVYEAR), 
    decimals = 1 
  ) |> 
  gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |> 
  gt::cols_label_with( 
    fn = function(x) {
      case_when(
        x == "pse" ~ gt::md("PSE attainment"),
        x == "newcomer" ~ gt::md("Newcomer representation"),
        x == "SURVYEAR" ~ gt::md("Year")
      )
    }
  ) |> 
  lfs_source_note(u = "Youth 15-29")

2.4.2 Key segments of the youth population
Figure 2.3 shows the distribution of youth in Canada across key segments from 2015 to 2024. The segments are defined by the intersection of educational enrollment, educational attainment, and newcomer status.


Show code
t04 <- d |> 
  filter(
    youth_lgl == 1,
    school_month
  ) |> 
  group_by(SURVYEAR, SURVMNTH) |> 
  count(segment, wt = FINALWT) |>
  mutate(p = n / sum(n)) |>
  group_by(segment) |>
  mutate(idx_15 = round(p / first(p) * 100) - 100) |>
  ungroup()

t04 |> 
  ggplot(aes(SURVMNTH, p)) +
  facet_grid(.~SURVYEAR) +  
  geom_path(aes(group = segment, color = segment)) + 
  scale_x_discrete(
    labels = function(x) stringr::str_sub(x, end = 1L), expand = expansion(c(0.01, 0.01))
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1)) +
  bptheme::theme_blueprint(plot_background_color = NA)








Figure 2.3





Figure 2.4 shows the percentage change in the representation of each segment in the youth population from January 2015. It highlights the dramatic proportional increase in the representation of non-student newcomers, especially those with PSE attainment (which has more than doubled) among Canadian youth.


Show code
t04 |> 
  ggplot(aes(SURVMNTH, idx_15)) +
  facet_grid(.~SURVYEAR) +  
  geom_path(aes(group = segment, color = segment)) + 
  scale_x_discrete(
    labels = function(x) stringr::str_sub(x, end = 1L), expand = expansion(c(0.01, 0.01))
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous() +
  bptheme::theme_blueprint(plot_background_color = NA)








Figure 2.4





Figure 2.5 disaggregates the total shift in segment representation from January 2015 to December 2024 by province.
In absolute terms, representation of newcomers with PSE among working-age youth increased in all provinces. PEI experienced the highest absolute increase (+3.4 ppt), while Saskatchewan experienced the lowest (+.5 ppt).


Show code
t05 <- d |> 
  filter(youth_lgl == 1, school_month) |> 
  group_by(SURVYEAR, PROV) |> 
  count(segment, wt = FINALWT) |> 
  mutate(p = n / sum(n)) |>
  group_by(PROV, segment) |> 
  summarize(
    delta_abs = last(p) - first(p),
    delta_idx = last(p) / first(p) - 1,
    .groups = "drop"
  )

t05 |> 
  ggplot(aes(delta_abs, PROV)) + 
  geom_col(aes(fill = segment), position = "dodge") +
  facet_wrap(~segment, nrow = 2) + 
  bptheme::theme_blueprint(plot_background_color = NA) + 
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1), breaks = seq(-.03, .03, .01))








Figure 2.5





Indexed to 2015 (Figure 2.6), the growth of both newcomer segments dwarfs changes in the others. For those segments, changes were most dramatic in the Atlantic provinces. Newfoundland and Labrador experienced the greatest relative increase, with the proportion of newcomers with PSE among working-age youth increasing by an order of magnitude (12.6 X)


Show code

  ggplot(aes(delta_idx, PROV)) + 
  geom_col(aes(fill = segment), position = "dodge") +
  facet_wrap(~segment, nrow = 2) + 
  bptheme::theme_blueprint(plot_background_color = NA) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    labels = function(x) {
      scales::number(x + 1, suffix = "x")
    }
  )
